stream_context.summary: The stream focused on implementing new graphical assets from artist Biobak for several course select screens. This involved animating a submarine, fixing complex visual artifacts with 3D models and lighting, and implementing an animated bird. Kaze also spent significant time debugging a compiler-related sine wave issue and discussed future plans for level themes and the game's overworld.

development_findings.summary: A significant amount of time was spent debugging an animation bug that was ultimately caused by the compiler silently failing to link the sine function correctly due to a missing header file.
development_findings.quote: What the fuck how can it just link garbage data and not tell me

development_findings.summary: Kaze follows a self-imposed design rule that all collectible stars must be placed at a consistent height (200 or 300 units) from the ground to ensure visibility and reachability.
development_findings.quote: So in RTY I actually have the guideline that every star is exactly 300 rounds off the floor. Fun fact.

development_findings.summary: A visual artifact on a 3D model (an 'X' shape on a cone) was fixed by completely remaking the model with higher polygon density, as tweaking vertex colors or textures was insufficient.

Kaze discussed potential themes for the final levels, including a Wild West level, a comic book/superhero level, and an Arctic/ice cream level, while firmly rejecting the idea of a music-themed level.
development_findings.quote: The last four level themes are not set in stone.

development_findings.summary: The game's overworld is planned for a complete redesign, with a new concept based on a tropical island theme inspired by Mario Party.
development_findings.quote: The entire overworld will be reworked, so nothing you see in the overworld is going to be the same.

development_findings.summary: A list of five planned 'Retro Sections' based on classic Nintendo games was revealed: Paper Mario 64, Mario Paint, Dr. Mario, Super Mario Land 1, and Super Smash Bros. 64.
An engine limitation was discovered where object animations freeze during the fade-out transition when selecting a level, which Kaze identified as a significant issue that needs to be fixed.
development_findings.quote: Right now the animation just freezes while the fadeout is happening and that's a big deal.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes in separating the art from the artist, intentionally keeping his presence out of the game itself to protect the player's experience from any future controversies about him.
context_findings.quote: The player shouldn't even know that I exist when he plays this game. That way, if in the future I get cancelled on Twitter, no one has to put down the game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and his wife, Zeina, are moving house the day after the stream. He states his future streams will take place in his new office, which he refers to as the 'case dungeon'.

When a viewer offered money to have their comment pinned on a YouTube video, Kaze declined, explaining that the potential loss of viewership and engagement from an irrelevant pinned comment is more significant than a small monetary donation.
context_findings.quote: The views I lose from having unnecessary stuff like that pinned is far outweighing your five bucks.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions he has not played Mario Wonder yet and thinks about his future personal life, stating he plans to play it with his kids one day.
context_findings.quote: I haven't played Mario Wonder, I'm planning to play it with my kids in like 5 years or something.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided several new graphical assets for course select screens, including a submarine model and an animated spooky lights effect.
Kaze frequently communicated with Biobak (who was in the chat) to clarify animation details, such as asking if a sine wave for an animation should be slowed down or phase-shifted.
biobak.quote: Did you maybe mean that one of them was offset by 0.5?

biobak.summary: Kaze initially defers to Biobak's artistic direction on animation choices, showing a collaborative dynamic.
biobak.quote: I'll listen to Biobak. If he says don't animate them on the Z-axis, then that's what's gonna be.

biobak.summary: Despite his willingness to collaborate, Kaze ultimately overruled Biobak's suggestion to keep clouds static, deciding to add vertical movement because he felt it looked better.
biobak.quote: Nah, I think Biobak's wrong on this one. We're definitely gonna make the clouds move up and down.

zeina.summary: When asked about a previous project (Donkey Donkey Mario 64), Zeina recalled being 'traumatized' by one of the characters, giving a glimpse into her shared history with Kaze's past work.
zeina.quote: I think maybe the weeb toad because it was so traumatizing that I... That's the only character I can remember.

zeina.summary: Zeina revealed that the pink bob-omb in a past game was inspired by Skellux, a prominent community member, but playfully refused to elaborate further when Kaze asked for the story.
zeina.quote: If you remember anything about it, you would know.

key_stories.title: The Phantom Sine Wave
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to debug an erratic submarine animation. After confirming his logic was correct, he discovered the compiler was silently failing to link the sine function due to a missing header, causing it to use garbage data and revealing a deep-seated toolchain issue.
key_stories.challenge: A submarine model animated with a sine wave function was moving erratically and unpredictably, despite the code appearing correct.
key_stories.process: Kaze first tried debugging by checking the math and printing the input values to the sine function, which all seemed correct. This led him to suspect an external issue. He eventually realized that a necessary header file was missing, causing the compiler to behave in an unexpected and silent way.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze discovered the compiler was linking to garbage data because the 'math.h' header was not included, but it wasn't throwing an error. Adding the include instantly fixed the problem, highlighting a frustrating quirk in the development toolchain.
key_stories.key_quote: How did it just link the sign table to a random thing instead of telling me that there's no sign table? I take no blame for that.

key_stories.title: Fixing the Shading Artifact
key_stories.summary: When implementing a lighting effect from Biobak, Kaze noticed an ugly 'X' artifact caused by vertex shading. After simple fixes failed, he rebuilt the 3D model from scratch with more polygons, successfully smoothing out the shading and fixing the visual bug.
key_stories.challenge: A spooky light effect designed by Biobak had ugly visual artifacts, including an 'X' shape appearing on the light cones, which was caused by vertex shading on the low-polygon models.
key_stories.process: Kaze initially suspected the issue was with vertex colors or textures. After confirming the problem was the shading on the vertices of the low-poly model, he decided the best solution was to completely remake the model from scratch with more geometry to create a smoother surface for the lighting to apply to.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully removed the artifact by recreating the cone models with a higher polygon count, resulting in a smooth light gradient that matched the artist's original vision.
key_stories.key_quote: I got rid of the axe. You think it's better like this? I think it is.

key_stories.title: The Frozen Bird
key_stories.summary: Kaze worked on an animated bird that should fly away when a level is selected. He discovered a major engine limitation where all animations freeze during the screen fade-out, cutting the bird's animation short. He postponed a proper fix due to its complexity.
key_stories.challenge: When implementing an animated bird for a level select screen, Kaze needed it to fly away gracefully after the player selected a star.
key_stories.process: Kaze successfully implemented the bird's idle animations. However, upon testing the take-off animation triggered by a button press, he discovered the entire game state, including object animations, pauses during the screen fade transition. He deemed a fix too complex for the current stream.
key_stories.outcome: The bird's take-off animation was cut short because all object animations freeze during the level fade-out. Kaze identified this as a core engine problem that needs to be fixed later, leaving the feature in a partially working state.
key_stories.key_quote: Everything just freezes when I press A. That's problematic. Because I do want the bird to update. But I think this function stops running.

open_questions.context: Zeina revealed that the pink bob-omb character in a past game, 'Donkey Donkey Mario 64', was inspired by community member Skellux. Kaze seemed unaware of this lore and Zeina refused to elaborate on stream.
questions: What is the story behind the pink bob-omb being based on Skellux?
What aspects of Skellux's personality or history inspired the character's creation and dialogue?
How do you feel about embedding community-specific lore into your games?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated the game's entire overworld will be scrapped and redesigned with a 'tropical island' theme inspired by Mario Party. He gave no further details on the layout or mechanics.
questions: What was the catalyst for deciding to completely rework the overworld?
What specific elements or feelings from Mario Party are you trying to capture in the new design?
How will navigation work on this new island? Will it feature mechanics like fast travel?
What is the process for designing a new overworld from scratch for an existing set of levels?

open_questions.context: The stream was titled 'Working on All-Black Boss', but Kaze explicitly stated no work would be done on it, mentioning that most of its development happens off-stream.
questions: Can you describe the concept for the 'All-Black Boss'?
What are the main gameplay mechanics of this boss fight?
Why has the development for this specific feature happened primarily off-stream compared to other parts of the game?

open_questions.context: Kaze listed the five planned retro sections (Paper Mario, Mario Paint, etc.) but commented, 'I'm not 100% happy with them,' without specifying his concerns.
questions: Which of the planned retro sections are you uncertain about, and what are your specific concerns?
What are the core gameplay concepts you've designed for each of these retro stages?
Are you still considering swapping any of them out? If so, what are some of the alternate ideas you've considered?
